resources.string: Satipatthāna is the Pāli word for the Buddhist concept of the foundations of mindfulness. ‘Noting’ is a powerful way to cultivate Satipatthāna. This method involves tracking your subjective experience in terms of sights, sounds, and feelings, both physical and mental. It’s about appreciating yourself just as you are.
You should first go to the monastery and study the fundamentals of Noting and Satipatthāna.
It is time for you to observe your world with diligence and precision. Go meditate!
I have observed you carefully and you have great potential.
Excellent first session. Meet me here again when you are ready.
In your last session, your noting speed was very rapid. You are beginning to see the impermanence of all sensory phenomena.
You are becoming more in tune with your body sensations and emotions. You are realizing that suffering is inescapable.
You are beginning to see your thoughts arise and pass away.

string-array.name: monastery_ideas
string-array.item: \nContinuously track any visual thoughts that may come up spontaneously. These will present as “mental images”, and they may be strong or weak, long or short.\n
\nIf mental talk occurs, listen to it with detachment, neither suppressing it nor holding on to it. Many thoughts take the form of this “mental chatter”.\n
\nWhen you experience an emotion, it will almost certainly involve detectable body sensations in addition to mental talk and mental images. Feel these emotions in your stomach and face.\n
\nEach time your attention shifts from one object to another or from one place in an object to a different place in that object, note that shift as a new sight experience.\n
\nFocus on external sounds, either those naturally occurring around you or sounds that you like and have chosen to play.\n
\nAt any given moment, physical body sensations may arise in just one location, in several locations, or over your whole body at once.\n

string-array.name: monastery_instructions
string-array.item: \nWhenever you have a mental image, note that as “See In.” Whenever all or part of the image drops away or drops off, note that as “Gone.”
\nWhenever you have mental talk, note that as “Hear In.” Whenever a burst of talk drops off or drops away, note that as “Gone.”
\nWhenever your experience is in any way emotional, that emotion may involve body experience. If so, note that as “Feel In.” If a “Feel In” sensation drops off, note that as “Gone.”
\nEach time your line of sight shifts, note “See Out.” It does not matter if the shift is spontaneous or intentional. If you happen to note the preceding sight drop away or drop off, note “Gone.”
\nWhenever you’re aware of sound, note “Hear Out.” If all or part of the sound drops away or drops off, note “Gone.”
\nWhenever you’re aware of a physical body sensation, note “Feel Out.” If all or part of that sensation drops away or drops off, note “Gone.”
